crdo:item.dc:title: Sister: The sister's wedding (version 1)
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: Le mariage de la soeur (version 1)
摩梭人丧葬仪式中的“斯克”仪式是怎么来的？（第一次讲述版本）
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ɑ˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dcterms:abstract: This myth narrates the origin of the ritual called "sɯ˧kʰɯ˩", which is conducted after the decease of a woman who got married and therefore left the house where she was born. Marriage stands in contradiction to the earlier Na family structure: traditionally, children spent their entire lives in their mother's home, together with their relatives on the mother's side (their brothers and sisters, their mother's brothers and sisters, their cousins on the mother's side, and so on). The ritual "sɯ˧kʰɯ˩" reflects the pain that Chinese-style (virilocal) marriage represents for the bride's family, as it loosens the ties between a woman and her original home.

crdo:item.dc:title: Naxi songs from Tacheng, by Ms. XIAO Rulian
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 肖汝连先生塔城纳西语歌曲
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dc:description: The recording of the six songs presented here was generously arranged by the son of Ms. Xiao Rulian, the Naxi singer and artist He Wenguang. Heartfelt thanks are due to Mr. He for his enthusiastic response to my suggestion of making this recording--a token of his lifelong dedication to the preservation of Naxi art.
肖汝莲，是丽江市塔城乡著名纳西族民间歌手。录音时（2002年），肖汝莲女士73岁。肖汝莲女士的儿子，纳西族歌手和文光先生安排我录她母亲的音，给予了大力帮助，在此万分感谢！希望我的录音工作对喜爱纳西歌曲、纳西文化、纳西语的人士能尽一点绵薄之力。 这六首歌没有通过任何处理，是直接从DAT母带转录而来的。
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: Traditional songs from the Naxi town of Tacheng (塔城)

crdo:item.dc:title: Dape
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 宁蒗彝族自治县拉伯乡拉伯村
Labai village, Labai township, Yongning County, Lijiang Municipality, Yunnan, China
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: Work with Lamu Gatusa only extended over two sessions, on August 11th and August 12th, 2009. The second session was recorded. This is an exploratory elicitation session: the items were transcribed as they were being said; the speaker and the investigator discussed in Chinese over the meaning of words, cases of homophony, issues of transcription, and so on. The purpose was to devise a first version of a transcription system in the International Phonetic Alphabet, which Mr. Lamu would then use (and develop further) for transcribing Na stories, proverbs and rituals and preparing annotated bilingual editions. A note about Mr. Lamu Gatusa's name: his name in Na is /lɑ˧mbv˧ kɤ˧tʰv˥sɑ˥/. The phonetic approximation of this Na name in Mandarin Chinese is Lamu Gatusa (Chinese characters: 拉木•嘎吐萨). His pen-name is 石高峰: Shi Gaofeng.

crdo:item.dc:title: Dog: How dog and man exchanged their lifespan (speaker M28; Labai dialect)
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 宁蒗彝族自治县拉伯乡拉伯村
Labai village, Labai township, Yongning County, Lijiang Municipality, Yunnan, China
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a story about how dog and man exchanged their lifespan; it explains why the Na/Mosuo give dogs a special place in rituals.
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: Chien : comment le chien et l'homme ont échangé leur longévité (version 3)
人与狗换寿命（第三次讲述版本）

crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 宁蒗彝族自治县拉伯乡拉伯村
Labai village, Labai township, Yongning County, Lijiang Municipality, Yunnan, China
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a story about the origin of the Lake: how it was created by a flood.

crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a story about separated siblings. It explains the origin of an important Na/Mosuo ritual.

crdo:item.dc:title: Adopting pets: dogs and cats
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This explanation stems from a misunderstanding. I asked what people thought about this and that year in the Chinese horoscope (生肖), such as 'the year of the Dog'; my intention was to elicit explanations about how different years (year of the Tiger, etc) were perceived by the Na, which properties were attributed to them. This was misunderstood as 'what did people think about stealing dogs'.

crdo:item.dc:title: Cooking habits: A humorous saying about the Na, Pumi and Han (Chinese)
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is an explanation about a humorous saying about the Na, Pumi and Han (Chinese). The Han check how the cooking is going by lifting the lid, whereas the Na and Pumi busily add more and more wood to the fire without taking a look inside the pot. The narrator elaborates on this small piece of ethnic self-deprecation.

crdo:item.dc:title: Daba: the priest of the local religion (version 1)
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: Memories about the traditional Na religion. The speaker does not know about the detailed contents of the rituals ; this is a description of the occasions on which the priest was invited to conduct rituals. The short title of the document is the romanized (Pinyin) transcription of the term used in Chinese to refer to these ritual practitioners : 达巴.

crdo:item.dc:title: Founding New Home: How families handle situations where the family members are so numerous that the house cannot accommodate them all anymore
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is an account of how families split: when the family members were so numerous that the house could not accommodate them anymore. (In more recent times: the 1970s, families had to split when marriage was imposed on the Na and traditional lifestyle was forbidden: the food rations of families were cut until they adopted the new, 'modern' family structure, with one man, his wife and children under the same roof. The narrative carefully avoids mention of these events in recent history.)

crdo:item.dc:title: Introduction: A message to listeners of the recordings placed online for public access
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This was recorded as an oral "informed consent", making explicit the speaker's willingness to have anyone listen to these materials. Despite some misgivings on the part of the investigator about eliciting a message that could be interpreted as a "copyright transfer", it appeared useful to record this explicit statement about the speaker's view of the documents and their eventual online availability.

crdo:item.dc:title: Singing: a conversational account of how and when the Na used to sing
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is not a song, but a conversational account of how and when the Na used to sing. The tempo is slightly slow, as the speaker tries to think of things to say on this topic.

crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is an addition to the presentation of spirits in the recording "Ghosts and Spirits", explaining that there were two spirits in a sanctuary close to the Yongning monastery.

crdo:item.dc:title: Swinging: a leisure activity of the old times
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This narrates how people built swings for the New Year, as a means of entertainment.

crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na

crdo:item.dc:title: Taboos: an account of prohibitions in daily life
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is an account of prohibitions in daily life: one must not whistle within the house; one must not throw garbage into the fire; one must not drop things (such as firewood) heavily in the main room (the hearth); one must not spill water into the hearth...
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ə˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

crdo:item.dc:title: Taking charge of rituals: how the narrator takes charge of rituals at the request of others
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This recording explains how the narrator takes charge herself on many ceremonial occasions, such as children’s coming of age and marriages.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ə˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

crdo:item.dc:title: Terrestrial branches: properties associated with one's year of birth
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is an account of what people thought about this and that year in the Chinese horoscope (生肖), such as 'the year of the Dog', 'the year of the Tiger, etc: how the Terrestrial Branches were perceived by the Na, which properties were attributed to them. People born in the year of the Tiger are strong, people born in the year of the Rabbit are fast, etc.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ə˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

crdo:item.dc:title: Tooth: how a fake relic became a real one
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This recording narrates how a young man who studied Tibetan Buddhism in Lhasa came back empty-handed, without a gift for his mother ; on the way, he plucked a tooth from a dead horse and told his mother it was a god’s tooth. His mother marvelled at this extraordinary gift and prayed three times a day to the tooth. Her faith was so intense that the tooth, originally a fake relic, eventually started to blaze and sparkle.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ə˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

crdo:item.dc:title: Trader and his son: how a trader taught his son how to handle the ups and downs of commerce
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: A narrative about how a trader taught his son to manage trade wisely. To his son’s surprise, the father asked him to collect stories along the way, as gifts to the father, instead of buying presents. The father’s message was that traders must avoid being left without sufficient stocks of food when they come back, and therefore should not spend their money hastily on pretty objects on sale at distant places.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ə˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

crdo:item.dc:title: Trading
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a description of trade in the old times (about the middle of the 20th century), which was provided, in conversational mode, after the recording of the story « Trader and his son ». The speaker provides some explanations about how hemp clothes, one of the commodities produced in Yongning, used to be produced and sold.

crdo:item.dc:title: DIALOGUES 1: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is one of 3 original files: it contains the audio for speaker M4 (see description).
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: DIALOGUES 1: Dialogues lus, conçus pour une étude phonétique portant sur l'influence de l'attitude du locuteur sur la réalisation de deux particules finales du vietnamien de Hanoi
ĐỐI THOẠI 1: Đối thoại được thiết kế cho việc nghiên cứu sự biến đổi đặc tính âm học của hai trợ từ tình thái cuối câu trong Tiếng Việt, thể hiện theo các thái độ khác nhau (Hà Nội)
crdo:item.dc:subject: Hanoi dialect
Vietnamese
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications
Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: Information on FORM: This file (audio signal for speaker M4) is one of the three channels that constitute the entire resource. The present audio file is the audio signal collected for speaker M4. In addition to this file, there exist two other data files: EGG signal for speaker M4; and audio signal for speaker M5. Finally, a fourth file was created for ease of consultation by mixing the two audio channels into a (single-channel) WAV file. These files were also deposited in the archive. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.

These 3 files were also deposited in the archive. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. crdo:item.dc:title: DIALOGUES 1: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is an EDITED file, not an original (see description).
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: DIALOGUES 1: Dialogues lus, conçus pour une étude phonétique portant sur l'influence de l'attitude du locuteur sur la réalisation de deux particules finales du vietnamien de Hanoi
ĐỐI THOẠI 1: Đối thoại được thiết kế cho việc nghiên cứu sự biến đổi đặc tính âm học của hai trợ từ tình thái cuối câu trong Tiếng Việt, thể hiện theo các thái độ khác nhau (Hà Nội)
crdo:item.dc:subject: Hanoi dialect
Vietnamese
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications
Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: Information on FORM: This document (audio+EGG) is an edited version of the document Dialogues1, retaining only the sentences that were relevant for a study of sentence-final particles conducted in 2013. During data processing, the data sets for speakers M4 and M5 were edited to retain only the passages relevant for analysis. These documents are less complete than the set presented with XML annotation/transcription, and they are not time-aligned between the two speakers; they are nonetheless made available, in case they should be of interest, for instance to someone who wished to replicate our measurements over the data for all four speakers. In the version made available here, each file is annotated with the SoundForge software. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.

During data processing, the data sets for speakers M4 and M5 were edited to retain only the passages relevant for analysis. These documents are less complete than the set presented with XML annotation/transcription, and they are not time-aligned between the two speakers; they are nonetheless made available, in case they should be of interest, for instance to someone who wished to replicate our measurements over the data for all four speakers. In the version made available here, each file is annotated with the SoundForge software. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.

Vietnamese
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications
Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit. The documents from M6 and M7 are not complete dialogues: speakers M6 and M7 are colleagues at the MICA institute. They managed the task themselves: the interviewer served as dialogue partner when requested; otherwise the speakers only read the target sentences, in the manner they deemed most appropriate to convey the intended attitude. Each file is annotated with the SoundForge software.

crdo:item.dc:title: The Naxi priest He Xuewen reads the Great Prayer to the Wind
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 纳西东巴和学文读《大祭风》仪式(音译："崇般崇笮")
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省丽江市玉龙纳西族自治县太安乡吉子村汝南化
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: The Naxi priest He Xuewen (1922-2007) reads the Great Prayer to the Wind. This is rhythmic reading, not full-fledged chanting. The same text was also chanted on the same day (before the rhythmic reading). The volume of the recording has not been modified (no digital normalization of the volume), so that it can be directly compared with the volume of the chanted version of the text. The text was read from the pictographic manuscript reproduced on pp. 151-167 of the following book: Nàxī Dōngbā Gǔjí Yìzhù 纳西东巴古籍译注 (An Annotated Translation of Naxi Dongba Classical Texts), Volume 1, by He Kaixiang, He Shicheng, Wang Shiying, and Li Jingsheng (Kunming: Yunnan Minzu Chubanshe, 1987). Special thanks are due to Pr. Guo Dalie for suggesting to Mr. He Xuewen to perform for this recording.

crdo:item.dc:title: The Naxi priest He Xuewen chants the Great Prayer to the Wind
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 纳西东巴和学文朗诵《大祭风》仪式(音译："崇般崇笮")
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省丽江市玉龙纳西族自治县太安乡吉子村汝南化
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: The Naxi priest He Xuewen (1922-2007) reads the Great Prayer to the Wind. The same text was also read on the same day as rhythmic reading, without chanting. The text was read from the pictographic manuscript reproduced on pp. 151-167 of the following book: Nàxī Dōngbā Gǔjí Yìzhù 纳西东巴古籍译注 (An Annotated Translation of Naxi Dongba Classical Texts), Volume 1, by He Kaixiang, He Shicheng, Wang Shiying, and Li Jingsheng (Kunming: Yunnan Minzu Chubanshe, 1987). Special thanks are due to Pr. Guo Dalie for suggesting to Mr. He Xuewen to perform for this recording.

crdo:item.dc:title: Ballad about hunting (Romanized Naxi: Kee Keel; IPA: /kʰɯ˧kʰɯ˥/)
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省丽江市玉龙纳西族自治县拉市乡南尧行政村
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a sung version, in the "Guqi" style (骨气调), of a passage from the ballad about hunting, /kʰɯ˧kʰɯ˥/ (Romanized Naxi: "Kee Keel"). This is the beginning of the ballad. A monolingual edition of this long popular ballad, in Naxi orthography, was published in 1987 in Kunming. Title: Kee Keel ; Chinese references: title: 猎歌（纳西文）; editors: 李即善, and 和学才; place published: Kunming 昆明; publisher: 云南民族出版社（YUIQNAIQ MIQCVF CVFBAISHEL）. The sound was collected by a Sony electret microphone 35 cm from the mouth of the singer. This is one of the vocal performances recorded at the suggestion of Naxi scholar Guo Dalie, who arranged for me to meet the singer Li Xiuxiang, from the village of Lashi (born in 1945). At the time Mrs. Li had been performing in Lijiang for several years, but no recordings were available. Heartfelt thanks are due to Mrs. Li for generously accepting to do this recording, intended for the preservation of her voice and its transmission to a large audience; to Guo Dalie and the Museum of Dongba Culture, for making the recording possible; and to the Naxi priest He Xuewen for kindly inviting us to do the recording at his residence within the Museum of Dongba Culture.
2002年，郭大烈老师为了保存纳西口传文化遗产，建议我录制著名艺人李秀香女士的歌曲。李秀香是丽江拉市海北南尧村人，擅长演唱多种不同风格的纳西歌曲。 在此非常感谢郭大烈老师与丽江东巴文化博物馆领导们的建议与大力支持，也感谢已故的和学文先生出借了他在东巴文化博物馆内的房间进行录音。 这些资料没有通过任何处理，是直接从DAT母带转录而来。
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 猎歌（纳西文：Kee Keel）

crdo:item.dc:title: Lv Bber Lv Ssaq: A passage from the ritual for lovers who committed suicide
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省丽江市玉龙纳西族自治县拉市乡南尧行政村
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a sung version, in the "Guqi" style (骨气调), of a passage from the ritual Lv Bber Lv Ssaq (phonetic transcription: lv˧bə˞˧ lv˧zɑ˩; phonetic approximation by means of Chinese characters: 鲁般鲁烧), a ritual that used to be performed after the suicide of lovers who committed suicide. The text was read from the International Phonetic Alphabet transcription on pp. 113-115 of the following book: Nàxī Dōngbā Gǔjí Yìzhù 纳西东巴古籍译注 (An Annotated Translation of Naxi Dongba Classical Texts), Volume 1, by He Kaixiang, He Shicheng, Wang Shiying, and Li Jingsheng (Kunming: Yunnan Minzu Chubanshe, 1987). The text on page 113 corresponds to the portion of the recordings from the beginning to 2mn 50s; page 114 to the portion from 2mn 50s to 5mn 06s. Reading is interrupted at the second line of page 115 ('second line' refers to the text in International Phonetic Alphabet). The sung text is much longer than the text of the ritual, due to the insertion of syllables at certain positions in the song: the syllables of the text slowly trickle into the slots designed for them inside the patterns of this singing style. The singer made pauses between each sentence/portion of text (each corresponding to about 7 seconds of singing) to look at the book and take the time to understand the passage. The transcription used in the book is the standard adopted for Lijiang Naxi, which is not exactly identical with M8's dialect (Nanyao village, Lashi): the transcription does not reflect the opposition of voiced stops and prenasalized stops, so that a syllable written as /dzɯ/ can correspond to either /ndzɯ/ or /dzɯ/ in her dialect, and /be/ to either /mbe/ or /be/. This, together with the complexity of the texts, explains why the singer made pauses between each 'stanza'. At her request, these intervening pauses were removed from the recording. The sound was collected by a Sony electret microphone 35 cm from the mouth of the singer. The sound was so intense that the left channel from the stereo microphone was highly saturated; it was discarded, retaining only the right channel, which had a less saturated signal. This is one of the vocal performances recorded at the suggestion of Naxi scholar Guo Dalie, who arranged for me to meet the singer Li Xiuxiang, from the village of Lashi (born in 1945). At the time Mrs. Li had been performing in Lijiang for several years, but no recordings were available. Heartfelt thanks are due to Mrs. Li for generously accepting to do this recording, intended for the preservation of her voice and its transmission to a large audience; to Guo Dalie and the Museum of Dongba Culture, for making the recording possible; and to the Naxi priest He Xuewen for kindly inviting us to do the recording at his residence within the Museum of Dongba Culture.
2002年，郭大烈老师为了保存纳西口传文化遗产，建议我录制著名艺人李秀香女士的歌曲。李秀香是丽江拉市海北南尧村人，擅长演唱多种不同风格的纳西歌曲。 在此非常感谢郭大烈老师与丽江东巴文化博物馆领导们的建议与大力支持，也感谢已故的和学文先生出借了他在东巴文化博物馆内的房间进行录音。 这些资料没有通过任何处理，是直接从DAT母带转录而来。
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 鲁般鲁烧。唱法：“骨气调”。

crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省丽江市玉龙纳西族自治县拉市乡南尧行政村

crdo:item.dc:description: The Naxi singer Li Xiuxiang (1945-) sings Xuq Jjil: Blessings (popular Naxi songs). Singing style: wɤ˧-mə˧-ndɑ˩. The song was sung from memory. Heartfelt thanks are due to Mrs. Li for generously accepting to do this recording, intended for the preservation of her voice and its transmission to a large audience; to Guo Dalie and the Museum of Dongba Culture, for making the recording possible; and to the Naxi priest He Xuewen for kindly inviting us to do the recording at his residence within the Museum of Dongba Culture.

crdo:item.dc:title: Jew's Harp: the Naxi singer Li Xiuxiang (1945-) plays the Jew's harp (in Naxi: mbɑ˧zi˧ʝi˧). The performance is accompanied by explanations in Naxi and in Chinese.

crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi

crdo:item.dc:description: The Naxi singer Li Xiuxiang (1945-) plays the Jew's harp (in Naxi: mbɑ˧zi˧ʝi˧). The instrumental portions are located from 2mn 08s to 2mn 40s and from 5mn19 to 6mn 54. Heartfelt thanks are due to Mrs. Li for generously accepting to do this recording, intended for the preservation of her voice and its transmission to a large audience; to Guo Dalie and the Museum of Dongba Culture, for making the recording possible; and to the Naxi priest He Xuewen for kindly inviting us to do the recording at his residence within the Museum of Dongba Culture.
2002年，郭大烈老师为了保存纳西口传文化遗产，建议我录制著名艺人李秀香女士的歌曲。李秀香是丽江拉市海北南尧村人，擅长演唱多种不同风格的纳西歌曲。 在此非常感谢郭大烈老师与丽江东巴文化博物馆领导们的建议与大力支持，也感谢已故的和学文先生出借了他在东巴文化博物馆内的房间进行录音。 这些资料没有通过任何处理，是直接从DAT母带转录而来。

crdo:item.dc:title: The Parrot And The Myna Birds: A song improvised in the "A-li-li" style. Consultant: M17.
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: China, Yunnan, municipality of Lijiang, Longshan township, village of Yixin
中国云南省丽江纳西族自治县龙山乡义新村
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a song improvised in the GuQi style. There exists a full transcription+annotation+translation. A similar song in the "GuQi" style was recorded earlier on the same day. The recording session was arranged at the instigation of Pr. He Xueguang. Mr. He Xuemin (M17) was hosted full-time at the Naxi Culture Education Centre that he had founded at his own home: a small-scale training centre plus museum. This 纳西文化传习中心 later became an Association: 纳西文化传习协会. At the Education Centre, Mr. He Xuemin took part in training sessions; he also composed texts in Romanized Naxi, read and annotated books in Romanized Naxi published in the 1980s, and read publications in Chinese about Naxi culture. Mr. He Xuemin, a connoisseur of Naxi arts, readily accepted to record some songs, with two friends of his. The recording took place at the home of one of his friends, in a room that had little reverberation thanks to an abundance of rugs and bedding linen. The transcription of M17's documents is less reliable than that of M3 and M4's, because both the investigator and the language consultant were novice. Mr. He Xuemin's native dialect, Huangshan, is close to that of A-Ser (the mother tongue of M3 and M4), but not fully identical. As most of my work in 2002 concerned the A-Ser dialect, I was not able to undertake a study of the Huangshan dialect; I have not recorded other data from this dialect since.
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 红嘴绿鹦哥与八哥鸟群（“阿里里”调）
Le Perroquet et les Mainates: chanson improvisée dans le style "A-li-li"

crdo:item.dc:title: Lovers' Song. Singing style: wɤ˧-mə˧-ndɑ˩. Consultants: M17 and M32.
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: China, Yunnan, municipality of Lijiang, Longshan township, village of Yixin
中国云南省丽江纳西族自治县龙山乡义新村
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a song in the wɤ˧-mə˧-ndɑ˩ style. The song is preceded by a brief explanation in Naxi: the song was sung by men and women, who appointed a time to sing together and meet. M32 (anonymous) is a friend of Mr. He Xuemin (M17). The recording took place at M32's home, in a room that had little reverberation thanks to an abundance of rugs and linen. This song is one of a set of four that were recorded that evening as a sample of the Naxi singing styles that the three participants liked.

crdo:item.dc:title: Ciending read vocabulary: reading of the first pages of a vocabulary list of Ciending Naxi by Xu Jirong, who is the author of the list and a native speaker
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
纳西语
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: From 2009 to 2011, Xu Jirong, then a research student at Yunnan University, and Alexis Michaud had sustained exchanges about the phonological analysis of Ciending Naxi, Xu Jirong's native language. This resulted in a joint publication in 2012: Michaud, Alexis and Xu Jirong 徐继荣. Xiānggélǐlā xiàn Cìēndīng cūn nàxīyǔ yīnxì yánjiū 香格里拉县次恩丁村纳西语音系研究 [Research about the phonemic system of the Naxi dialect of Ciending village, Shangri-la prefecture]. Chama Gudao Yanjiu Jikan 茶马古道研究集刊 2. 139–165. The article contained a co-authored phonemic analysis, and a word list by Xu Jirong. On November 1st, 2013, Jirong agreed to record part of the vocabulary list (as Alexis was in Kunming on the way back from fieldwork). Some notations were corrected in the process. Due to time constraints (only one evening was available for this task), it was only possible to go through about one third of the list. This document provides phonetic evidence on this Naxi dialect, which presents some oppositions lost in some other dialects (see the article for details). Items are arranged roughly by alphabetical order: æ, b, ɕ, ç, d, ɖ... Many thanks to Mike Opper, a graduate student from Michigan University, in whose flat the recording was conducted, and who kindly provided mattresses and household linen to prop against the walls to decrease reverberation. Mike Opper and Meng Yang, a graduate from Ottawa University, were present during the recording.
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: 香格里拉县次恩丁村纳西语的一些词汇
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省迪庆州香格里拉县（从先中甸县。纳西语：ɳɖʐɯ˩dy˩）三坝纳西族乡（纳西语：bʋ˧ɖɛ˞˧）东坝行政村（纳西语：kɯ˧˥dy˩）次恩丁自然村 （纳西语：tsʰɯ˧˥ ɯ˧ ʈɯ˧）
Ciending hamlet, Dongba village, Sanba county, Zhongdian prefecture, Diqing, Yunnan, China

crdo:item.dc:title: A propaganda song to the glory of Chairman Mao, adapted to Tibxx. [Substitute 'et' for 'xx'] This song is sung in Chinese.
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
crdo:item.dc:description: A song adapted in 1972 from a propaganda song of 1964 to the glory of Chairman Mao:《北京的金山上》. This song was popularized (in its Chinese and Tibetan versions) by the singer Tseten Dolma (才旦卓玛), born 1937.

Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher. The items are not lexical: the reading task is based on the writing system: Naxi Pinyin 纳西拼音 (in Naxi: Naqxi Piyi).

A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dc:title: Monosyllabic words read in carrier sentence by consultant F2; reading condition: 'Impatient'
crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

crdo:item.dc:title: Vocabulary list for the Tai Yo dialect in Tuong Duong, part 1 of 5
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: Vocabulaire tai yo de Tuong Duong, partie 1 sur 5
Vốn từ vựng phương ngữ tiếng Thái Do ở Tương Dương, phần 1/5
crdo:item.dc:subject: Tai Yo
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a recording of selected items from the EFEO-SOAS-CNRS word list for linguistic fieldwork in Southeast Asia. The purpose of this work was not to study the entire vocabulary of the language, but to make a recording of a representative sample of the sounds of the language. The Tai Yo translation was written by the consultant on a paper copy of the word list, then read. This document concerns items carrying UID 1 to 380.

Đây là tệp tin ghi âm các mục đã được lựa chọn trước trong bảng từ do EFEO-SOAS-CNRS biên soạn phục vụ cho việc điều tra điền dã ngôn ngữ ở Đông Nam Á. Mục đích của công việc ghi âm này không phải là để nghiên cứu toàn bộ vốn từ của một ngôn ngữ, mà chỉ là mẫu đại diện cho âm thanh của ngôn ngữ đó. Bản dịch vốn từ tiếng Tai Yo được cộng tác viên viết trên bản sao của bảng từ điều tra, sau đó mới đọc. Các mục trong tài liệu này thuộc UID từ 1 đến 380.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Việt Nam, tỉnh Nghệ An, huyện Tương Dương, xã Yên Hòa, bản Xiềng Líp
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications

crdo:item.dc:title: Reading of Tai Yo idioms and proverbs
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: Lecture de dictons et proverbes
Đọc thành ngữ và tục ngữ tiếng Thái Do
crdo:item.dc:subject: Tai Yo
crdo:item.dc:description: Reading of the Tai Yo idioms and proverbs (from n°638 to 686 following Vi Kham Mun's notation). The transcription uses a romanization system that the consultant devised on the basis of Vietnamese orthography: see "Tục ngữ và thành ngữ người Thái Mương" (Trần Trí Dõi & Vi Khăm Mun, 2013).

Đọc thành ngữ và tục ngữ tiếng Thái Do (từ câu số 638 đến 686 theo cách chú của Vi Khăm Mun). Bản thảo này sử dụng hệ thống ghi âm do người cung cấp thông tin sáng tạo ra dựa trên hệ chữ viết của tiếng Việt: có thể xem kiểu chữ này trong cuốn "Tục ngữ và thành ngữ người Thái Mương (Trần Trí Dõi - Vi Khăm Mun, 2013).
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications

crdo:item.dc:title: Vocabulary list for the Tai Yo dialect in Tuong Duong, part 4 of 5
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: Vocabulaire tai yo de Tuong Duong, partie 4 sur 5
Vốn từ vựng phương ngữ tiếng Thái Do ở Tương Dương, phần 4/5
crdo:item.dc:subject: Tai Yo
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a recording of selected items from the EFEO-SOAS-CNRS word list for linguistic fieldwork in Southeast Asia. The purpose of this work was not to study the entire vocabulary of the language, but to make a recording of a representative sample of the sounds of the language. The Tai Yo translation was written by the consultant on a paper copy of the word list, then read. This document concerns items carrying UID 107 to 596.

Đây là tệp tin ghi âm các mục đã được lựa chọn trước trong bảng từ do EFEO-SOAS-CNRS biên soạn phục vụ cho việc điều tra điền dã ngôn ngữ ở Đông Nam Á. Mục đích của công việc ghi âm này không phải là để nghiên cứu toàn bộ vốn từ của một ngôn ngữ, mà chỉ là mẫu đại diện cho âm thanh của ngôn ngữ đó. Bản dịch vốn từ tiếng Tai Yo được cộng tác viên viết trên bản sao của bảng từ điều tra, sau đó mới đọc. Các mục trong tài liệu này thuộc UID từ 107 đến 596.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Việt Nam, tỉnh Nghệ An, huyện Tương Dương, xã Yên Hòa, bản Xiềng Líp
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications

crdo:item.dc:title: Chinese translation of the 'Coming of age' narrative: after recording an account of his coming-of-age ceremony, in his native language, the consultant provides a summary in Mandarin Chinese
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
Lataddi Narua
crdo:item.dc:description: Chinese translation of the 'Coming of age' narrative: the consultant provides a summary in Mandarin Chinese. This document was recorded immediately after recording the account of his coming-of-age ceremony in his native language. This recording was done in a room that was not sound-treated, hence some reverberation.
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Wuzhiluo, Boshu village, Luguhu district, Yanyuan county, Liangshan, Sichuan, China

crdo:item.dc:title: Coming of age: the consultant looks back on how his coming-of-age ceremony was performed
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
Lataddi Narua
crdo:item.dc:description: Coming of age: the consultant looks back on how his coming-of-age ceremony was performed, and his own perception of it at the time. The narrative includes an anecdote about a misgiving he had later about a missing element in the ceremony. This recording was done in a room that was not sound-treated, hence some reverberation. The investigators' request was to record materials in Na; the choice of topic was left for the consultant to choose. The recording session took place on a Saturday afternoon from 3 to 5 pm.

crdo:item.dc:title: An exploratory recording of numeral-plus-classifier phrases: 1 to 10, with 9 different classifiers. Speaker M31, year 2015
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
Lataddi Narua
crdo:item.dc:description: An exploratory recording of numeral-plus-classifier phrases. The elicitation starts out from the 9 tonal categories of classifiers that are known to be distinguished in another dialect, from the Yongning plain (Michaud, Alexis. 2013. The tone patterns of numeral-plus-classifier phrases in Yongning Na: a synchronic description and analysis. In Nathan Hill & Tom Owen-Smith (eds.), Transhimalayan Linguistics. Historical and Descriptive Linguistics of the Himalayan Area, 275–311. Berlin: De Gruyter Mouton). These 9 different classifiers are elicited from speaker M31, a speaker of the Lataddi dialect (泸沽湖镇). The aim of this preliminary investigation is to find out which of the 9 classifiers have a tonally different behaviour in Lataddi. This recording was done in a room that was not sound-treated, hence some reverberation. In the transcriptions, Tones are indicated in two ways: (i) in surface-phonological transcription, and also (ii) in terms of the underlying categories: for instance, 'one piece' is transcribed as /ɖɯ˩-kʰwɤ˥˩/ (surface-phonological transcription), and its tone category is indicated as L.H, because the final falling contour is ascribed to an exceptionless phonological rule whereby tone-group-final H tones are realized with a falling contour (and tone-group-final L tones with a rising contour). The nine classifiers selected for this exploratory session exemplify the nine tonal categories of classifiers brought out for the Yongning dialect (speaker F4). In M31's speech as exemplified in this recording, four tonal sets of classifiers emerge; differences are few, however. The four categories brought out correspond to: - category 1: Yongning's H1, H2, and L1- category 2: Yongning's M1, L2, L3 and MH1- category 3: Yongning's M2- category 4: Yongning's MH2To verify whether there are additional categories or not, a larger-scale study would be necessary: systematic elicitation of the classifiers found in the Lataddi dialect, in association with a range of numbers. This study would be equivalent in scope to that conducted with speaker F4 for the Yongning dialect (Pingjing village).

crdo:item.dc:title: Family story: a narrative about the consultant's life course so far
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a narrative about the consultant's life story so far. It was recorded for the purpose of a phonetic study of connected-speech processes, in particular the hypo-articulation of function words. At the outset of the document, the consultant explains that, for wants of practice telling folk stories, he chose to tell about the history of his family.
家庭的故事：关于录音者的生活。本次录音的目的，是录长篇语料，为了研究语流中的语音变化，特别是虚词的弱化。录音人由于没有很多经验讲传统故事，于是选择了讲自己家庭的一些情况。录音时没有刻意“纯化”纳西语，语言使用比较随意，因此故事中出现看不少汉语借词。比如“因为”一词，既有固有词tsɿ̟˧gɤ˩nɯ˧，又有汉语借词i˧we˥。特别说明：故事即兴讲述，有时事件和人物有出入。

crdo:item.dc:title: Syllabic inventory: recording of a table of attested syllables
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
crdo:item.dc:description: This is a recording of the syllables found in this dialect of Naxi. Each syllable is said at least two times; often three or four times. The phonemic analysis on which this recording is based is the following: Michaud, Alexis & Likun He. 2015. Phonemic and tonal analysis of the Pianding dialect of Naxi (Dadong County, Lijiang Municipality). Cahiers de Linguistique - Asie Orientale 44(1). 1–35 plus online Appendices. Note that not all syllables were recorded: after recording, it was noticed that there also exist the following syllables: /pɚ˩/ 拔; /vɚ˩vɚ˧/ 有嚼劲; /cʰwæ˧/ (Chinese loanword) 圈; /cwæ˧/ (Chinese loanword) 卷; /ndzɿ̠˧/ 唱; /ljæ˧ (Chinese loanword) 两; /ŋe˥/ (Chinese loanword) 硬; /ŋɤ˧/ 我的; /ŋʋ̩˩/ 银; /ŋæ˩ (Chinese loanword) 挨; /ŋɑ˩/ 我; /tɚ˥/ 关; /tɯ˞˧/ 起疹; /twæ˧/ (Chinese loanword) 端; /tjɤ˧/ 使辛苦; /tje˧˥/ (Chinese loanword) 碟; /tjæ˧/ (Chinese loanword) 点; /tjɑ˧/ (Chinese loanword) 叼; /çwæ˥/ (Chinese loanword) 炫; /cʰɑ˧˥/ (Chinese loanword) 家; /ɟʏ˧/ 存在动词; /ɲɟʏ˧/ 硬.

crdo:item.dc:title: Origin: the myth of origin of the Naxi people
crdo:item.dcterms:alternative: Origine: le mythe d'origine des Naxi
纳西创世纪故事
crdo:item.dc:subject: Naxi
Southwestern Mandarin
crdo:item.dc:description: Premier enregistrement de langue naxi réalisé par A. Michaud (en 2002). Je venais de faire connaissance avec He Xuan (和漩, M1), alors étudiant à Pékin, qui avait accepté le principe de participer à une enquête linguistique. Sa soeur (和沁, F1), de passage à Pékin, avait accepté de participer à l'enregistrement. Après des enregistrements de dialogues traduits à l'avance, de mots, d'expressions..., on est passé au discours 'spontané': un récit et un dialogue. La requête, c'était: un récit suivi, quel qu'en soit le sujet. F1 a choisi la cosmogonie naxi: l'histoire du héros fondateur. Elle la raconte sur un ton conversationnel: avec le soin et l'application qui la caractérisent, mais sans se prendre trop au sérieux, bien consciente qu'elle ne connaît l'histoire que dans ses grandes lignes, et qu'il s'agit d'enregistrer du naxi parlé, non de produire une version canonique de ce récit traditionnel. Son frère et moi sommes présent dans le studio d'enregistrement du laboratoire de phonétique de l'Université Centrale des Nationalités (appartenant à l'Académie des Sciences Sociales de Chine: 中国科学院民族研究所语音学实验室); nous sommes tous trois assis autour d'une table. De temps en temps, elle lui adresse des demandes de confirmation, auxquelles il répond par quelques mots ou par un simple signe d'approbation.

crdo:item.dc:description: Appeal to the gods to settle a quarrel: in feudal times, when people had a disagreement that they were unable to settle, they would go to the monastery and present their point of view before the gods, swearing that they were telling the truth. The gods would then punish the guilty one [through plagues and misfortunes].

crdo:item.dc:description: Funeral: How funeral rites are conducted [2nd version]. [Note: the narrative was briefly interrupted at 4mn35seconds, when some people walked in, and again at 10mn39seconds, when the phone rang. The sound file was edited to remove these short passages. The thread of the narrative was not lost at the first interruption. After the second interruption, the investigator provides, as a cue to resume the narrative, a theme broached at 8mn38seconds on the recording: that bones must not be exposed to water.]

crdo:item.dc:title: Historical situation: the narrator reflects on her situation as a consultant providing knowledge about the Na language and Na traditions.
crdo:item.dc:subject: Yongning Na
Yongning Na
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ɑ˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
China, Yunnan Province, Lijiang Municipality, Ninglang Prefecture, Yongning County, ɑ˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧ Village
中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: This narrative began impromptu: I was explaining (in 'basic Na') a trip to Dadong 大东 the day before, with Naxi student He Likun, and the recordings that we had done, noting that some people who do not count as youngsters anymore (people in their forties or fifties, i.e. whom one could imagine to have been brought up in a relatively monolingual environment and to have had exposure to some oral traditions) were not very knowledgeable about Naxi traditions. F4 picks up this observation, and reflects on her own situation as a consultant providing knowledge about the Na language and Na traditions. She explains that she is not someone who belongs to the 'old world' of Na society before the 1950s: in a sense, she does not see herself as an 'elder'. The elders are now gone. On the other hand, she grew up in an extended family in which she could listen to a range of people, and she was an attentive listener.

crdo:item.dc:title: Historical situation, part 2: this is a sort of sequel to the narrative 'Historical situation'

crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: A sequel to 'Historical situation', emphasizing that the narrator is unlike some other members of her age group, who did not pay as much attention to the elders, and who are surprised these days when they hear her come up with stories and teachings that she remembers from her youth. (About half an hour after recording 'Historical situation', the narrator has further reminiscences and narrates this piece, explaining how the elders' knowledge was listened to less carefully by some than by others.)

crdo:item.dc:description: Mountain rites: about rites done for sacred mountains. The investigator asked for a narrative about the festival known in Chinese as 转山节 (about which F16 had already recorded a narrative). She chose to tell about all festivals involving mountains in the course of an entire year. Note: as a whole, the recording session conducted that day emphasized modern topics, modern tools, techniques and technology, and the vocabulary that came with them. This encouraged the consultant to use Chinese borrowings more lavishly than under previous circumstances, when the emphasis was on the old ways and the old ways.

crdo:item.dc:description: This is an explanation about the proverb “This year, even if we had had a thousand harvests, it would not have lasted a hundred years! This proverb is a consolation for years of bad harvests: “If the harvest had been excellent, it would not have lasted forever anyway! Everything begins anew every year, so let us look forward! Explication au sujet du proverbe qui dit : «Quand bien même on aurait fait une récolte fabuleuse, ça ne nous durerait pas éternellement: ça se rejoue chaque année!» Littéralement: «si, une année, mille récoltes parvenaient à maturité, on n['en] mangerait pas [pour autant pendant] cent ans =on n'aurait pas à manger pour cent ans!» Le proverbe sert à se consoler d'une mauvaise récolte, qui va obliger à une année frugale: «Si belle soit la récolte, elle n'aurait de toute façon pas duré éternellement; tout est à recommencer l'année suivante, voyons donc de l'avant!»
crdo:item.dc:title: Proverb: explaining a proverb: “Even if we had had a thousand harvests, it would not have lasted a hundred years!”

crdo:item.dc:description: Tone Tutorial: the investigator read tone patterns reported in the monograph about tone in Yongning Na (Michaud 2017), which at the time of recording was nearing completion. The consultant was asked to check whether those productions were correct and intelligible way. This was one of several methods for verifying the findings. Thus, this is not phonological elicitation, but a recording of a work session in which the investigator asked the consultant to check whether he realized the tone patterns in a correct and intelligible way. If a pattern was OK, the consultant repeated it. If it was not, she provided a correction. (Part 1 of 3.) This document covers: Table 5.6, Table 5.8, and Table 5.9.

crdo:item.dc:title: Read materials for the study of Vietnamese stop-final syllables (checked syllables): target words with tones D1, D2 and B2 in a carrier sentence. Careful reading. Used in the following phonetic study: Michaud, A. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61: 119–146.
crdo:item.dc:subject: Hanoi dialect
Vietnamese
crdo:item.dcterms:spatial: France, Paris area, Recorded at the recording booth of LIMSI-CNRS research centre
crdo:item.dc:contributor: Centre national de la recherche scientifique
crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: Read syllables in a carrier sentence. This data set was devised for the study of tones and final consonants in Hanoi Vietnamese. The speaker lived in Hanoi until he came to France (9 months before the date of recording). These data were used for the following study: Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. In the study, this speaker (aged 19 at the time of recording) is referred to as M1. (en)# Corpus conçu pour l'étude des consonnes finales et de leurs relations avec les tons en vietnamien de Hanoi. Les items lus par l’informateur sont des rimes, qui peuvent se combiner avec les initiales (attaques), ou apparaître telles quelles (un coup de glotte étant réalisé en début de syllabe). La liste épuise la combinatoire des noyaux vocaliques avec les finales (nasales et occlusives). Les rimes avec occlusives finales sont réalisées selon les deux possibilités tonales existant en vietnamien. Les rimes avec consonnes nasales finales peuvent porter l’un des six tons de base. Elles sont ici uniquement associées avec le ton étymologique B2 (ton nặng), qui comporte une glottalisation finale. En effet, le propos de l’enregistrement est de mettre en lumière le contraste entre, d'une part l'absence de glottalisation sur les syllabes à occlusive finale, quel que soit le ton, et d'autre part la glottalisation finale des syllabes sans occlusive finale au ton B2 (ton nặng). Trois des items sont des logatomes, qui n’apparaissent dans aucun mot existant. Cette situation a été discutée avec le locuteur, qui lit chacun des items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. La phrase-cadre est : Tôi đọc chữ _____ . « Je lis le caractère/la syllabe _____. » Les syllabes étaient écrites sur des cartes de papier, de sorte que le locuteur voyait les syllabes l’une après l’autre et non sous forme de liste, pour éviter qu’elle n’accentue le contraste entre éléments successifs (par exemple, accentuer la différence de voyelle entre ọp et ợp (14 et 15), accentuer la différence de consonne entre ạch et ạc (36 et 37), accentuer la différence tonale entre ắc et ặc (2 et 3)), ce qui aurait créé un biais. Les items n’étaient pas présentés par séries ordonnées pour éviter les effets de liste. L'enregistrement a été réalisé par le locuteur alors qu'il était arrivé en France depuis 9 mois. Le début de son apprentissage du français remontait à 1 an. Ces données ont été employées dans l'étude suivante : Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. Le locuteur y est désigné comme M1.

Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. In the study, this speaker (aged 19 at the time of recording) is referred to as M1. Les items lus par l’informateur sont des rimes, qui peuvent se combiner avec les initiales (attaques), ou apparaître telles quelles (un coup de glotte étant réalisé en début de syllabe). Les rimes avec occlusives finales sont réalisées selon les deux possibilités tonales existant en vietnamien. Les rimes avec consonnes nasales finales peuvent porter l’un des six tons de base. Elles sont ici uniquement associées avec le ton étymologique B2 (ton nặng), qui comporte une glottalisation finale. Trois des items sont des logatomes, qui n’apparaissent dans aucun mot existant. Cette situation a été discutée avec le locuteur, qui lit chacun des items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. (en)# Corpus conçu pour l'étude des consonnes finales et de leurs relations avec les tons en vietnamien de Hanoi. Les items lus par l’informateur sont des rimes, qui peuvent se combiner avec les initiales (attaques), ou apparaître telles quelles (un coup de glotte étant réalisé en début de syllabe). La liste épuise la combinatoire des noyaux vocaliques avec les finales (nasales et occlusives). Les rimes avec occlusives finales sont réalisées selon les deux possibilités tonales existant en vietnamien. Les rimes avec consonnes nasales finales peuvent porter l’un des six tons de base. Elles sont ici uniquement associées avec le ton étymologique B2 (ton nặng), qui comporte une glottalisation finale. En effet, le propos de l’enregistrement est de mettre en lumière le contraste entre, d'une part l'absence de glottalisation sur les syllabes à occlusive finale, quel que soit le ton, et d'autre part la glottalisation finale des syllabes sans occlusive finale au ton B2 (ton nặng). Trois des items sont des logatomes, qui n’apparaissent dans aucun mot existant. Cette situation a été discutée avec le locuteur, qui lit chacun des items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. Les syllabes étaient écrites sur des cartes de papier, de sorte que le locuteur voyait les syllabes l’une après l’autre et non sous forme de liste, pour éviter qu’elle n’accentue le contraste entre éléments successifs (par exemple, accentuer la différence de voyelle entre ọp et ợp (14 et 15), accentuer la différence de consonne entre ạch et ạc (36 et 37), accentuer la différence tonale entre ắc et ặc (2 et 3)), ce qui aurait créé un biais. Les items n’étaient pas présentés par séries ordonnées pour éviter les effets de liste. Le locuteur est né en 1979 à Hanoi (il avait 24 ans à la date de l’enregistrement). L'enregistrement a été réalisé par le locuteur alors qu'il était arrivé en France depuis 11 mois. Le début de son apprentissage du français remontait également à 11 mois. Ces données ont été employées dans l'étude suivante : Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. Le locuteur y est désigné comme M3.

crdo:item.dc:description: Read syllables in a carrier sentence. This data set was devised for the study of tones and final consonants in Hanoi Vietnamese. The speaker was born in 1980 in Hanoi. He lived in Hanoi until age 22, before coming to France (9 months before the date of recording). These data were used for the following study: Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. In the study, this speaker (aged 24 at the time of recording) is referred to as M3. (en)# Corpus conçu pour l'étude des consonnes finales et de leurs relations avec les tons en vietnamien de Hanoi. Les items lus par l’informatrice sont des rimes, qui peuvent se combiner avec les initiales (attaques), ou apparaître telles quelles (un coup de glotte étant réalisé en début de syllabe). La liste visait à épuiser la combinatoire des noyaux vocaliques avec les finales (nasales et occlusives), mais certaines rimes ont été omises par erreur: út ụt ụn / uốp uộp uộm / uốt uột uộn. Les rimes avec occlusives finales sont réalisées selon les deux possibilités tonales existant en vietnamien. Les rimes avec consonnes nasales finales peuvent porter l’un des six tons de base. Elles sont ici uniquement associées avec le ton étymologique B2 (ton nặng), qui comporte une glottalisation finale (soit au total 39*3=117 items). En effet, le propos de l’enregistrement est de mettre en lumière le contraste entre, d'une part l'absence de glottalisation sur les syllabes à occlusive finale, quel que soit le ton, et d'autre part la glottalisation finale des syllabes sans occlusive finale au ton B2 (ton nặng). Les trois derniers items sont des logatomes, qui n’apparaissent dans aucun mot existant. Cette situation a été discutée avec la locutrice, qui lit chacun des 117 items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. Les deux phrases-cadre sont : Tôi đọc chữ _____ . « Je lis le caractère/la syllabe _____. » Đây là chữ _____ cơ mà ! « Mais enfin, c’est le caractère/la syllabe _____ ! » Pour chaque syllabe, la locutrice la dit dans la première phrase-cadre, puis dans la seconde. Les syllabes étaient écrites sur des cartes de papier, de sorte que l’informatrice voyait les syllabes l’une après l’autre et non sous forme de liste, pour éviter qu’elle n’accentue le contraste entre éléments successifs (par exemple, accentuer la différence de voyelle entre ọp et ợp (14 et 15), accentuer la différence de consonne entre ạch et ạc (36 et 37), accentuer la différence tonale entre ắc et ặc (2 et 3)), ce qui aurait créé un biais. Les items n’étaient pas présentés par séries ordonnées pour éviter les effets de liste. L'enregistrement a été réalisé par la locutrice alors qu'elle était étudiante de Diplôme d'Etudes Approfondies (âgée de 24 ans), en France depuis seize mois environ (dont un séjour au Vietnam quelques mois avant l’enregistrement).

Cette situation a été discutée avec la locutrice, qui lit chacun des 117 items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. Les deux phrases-cadre sont : Tôi đọc chữ _____ . « Je lis le caractère/la syllabe _____. » Đây là chữ _____ cơ mà ! « Mais enfin, c’est le caractère/la syllabe _____ ! » Pour chaque syllabe, la locutrice la dit dans la première phrase-cadre, puis dans la seconde. Les syllabes étaient écrites sur des cartes de papier, de sorte que l’informatrice voyait les syllabes l’une après l’autre et non sous forme de liste, pour éviter qu’elle n’accentue le contraste entre éléments successifs (par exemple, accentuer la différence de voyelle entre ọp et ợp (14 et 15), accentuer la différence de consonne entre ạch et ạc (36 et 37), accentuer la différence tonale entre ắc et ặc (2 et 3)), ce qui aurait créé un biais. Les items n’étaient pas présentés par séries ordonnées pour éviter les effets de liste. L'enregistrement a été réalisé par la locutrice alors qu'elle était étudiante de Diplôme d'Etudes Approfondies (âgée de 24 ans), en France depuis seize mois environ (dont un séjour au Vietnam quelques mois avant l’enregistrement).

crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

crdo:item.dc:description: Information on FORM: This file (electroglottographic signal for speaker M5) is one of the three channels that constitute the entire resource. The present audio file is the electroglottographic signal collected for speaker M5. In addition to this file, there exist two other data files: audio signal for speaker M5; and audio signal for speaker M4. Finally, a fourth file was created for ease of consultation by mixing the two audio channels into a (single-channel) WAV file. These files were also deposited in the archive. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.

crdo:item.dc:description: Tone Tutorial: the investigator read tone patterns reported in the monograph about tone in Yongning Na (Michaud 2017), which at the time of recording was nearing completion. The consultant was asked to check whether those productions were correct and intelligible way. This was one of several methods for verifying the findings. Thus, this is not phonological elicitation, but a recording of a work session in which the investigator asked the consultant to check whether he realized the tone patterns in a correct and intelligible way. If a pattern was OK, the consultant repeated it. If it was not, she provided a correction. (Part 2 of 3.) This document covers: Table 5.10 and Table 5.11.

crdo:item.dc:description: Information on FORM: This document (audio+EGG) is an edited version of the document Dialogues1, retaining only the sentences that were relevant for a study of sentence-final particles conducted in 2013. During data processing, the data sets for speakers M4 and M5 were edited to retain only the passages relevant for analysis. These documents are less complete than the set presented with XML annotation/transcription, and they are not time-aligned between the two speakers; they are nonetheless made available, in case they should be of interest, for instance to someone who wished to replicate our measurements over the data for all four speakers. In the version made available here, each file is annotated with the SoundForge software. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.

crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

crdo:item.dc:description: Read syllables in a carrier sentence. This data set was devised for the study of tones and final consonants in Hanoi Vietnamese. The speaker lived in Hanoi until he came to France (9 months before the date of recording). These data were used for the following study: Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. In the study, this speaker (aged 24 at the time of recording) is referred to as M3. (en)# Corpus conçu pour l'étude des consonnes finales et de leurs relations avec les tons en vietnamien de Hanoi. Les items lus par l’informateur sont des rimes, qui peuvent se combiner avec les initiales (attaques), ou apparaître telles quelles (un coup de glotte étant réalisé en début de syllabe). La liste épuise la combinatoire des noyaux vocaliques avec les finales (nasales et occlusives). Les rimes avec occlusives finales sont réalisées selon les deux possibilités tonales existant en vietnamien. Les rimes avec consonnes nasales finales peuvent porter l’un des six tons de base. Elles sont ici uniquement associées avec le ton étymologique B2 (ton nặng), qui comporte une glottalisation finale. En effet, le propos de l’enregistrement est de mettre en lumière le contraste entre, d'une part l'absence de glottalisation sur les syllabes à occlusive finale, quel que soit le ton, et d'autre part la glottalisation finale des syllabes sans occlusive finale au ton B2 (ton nặng). Trois des items sont des logatomes, qui n’apparaissent dans aucun mot existant. Cette situation a été discutée avec le locuteur, qui lit chacun des items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. Les syllabes étaient écrites sur des cartes de papier, de sorte que le locuteur voyait les syllabes l’une après l’autre et non sous forme de liste, pour éviter qu’elle n’accentue le contraste entre éléments successifs (par exemple, accentuer la différence de voyelle entre ọp et ợp (14 et 15), accentuer la différence de consonne entre ạch et ạc (36 et 37), accentuer la différence tonale entre ắc et ặc (2 et 3)), ce qui aurait créé un biais. Les items n’étaient pas présentés par séries ordonnées pour éviter les effets de liste. Le locuteur est né en 1979 à Hanoi (il avait 24 ans à la date de l’enregistrement). L'enregistrement a été réalisé par le locuteur alors qu'il était arrivé en France depuis 11 mois. Le début de son apprentissage du français remontait également à 11 mois. Ces données ont été employées dans l'étude suivante : Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. Le locuteur y est désigné comme M3.

Hanoi dialect

crdo:item.dc:description: Mountain rites: about rites done for sacred mountains. The investigator asked for a narrative about the festival known in Chinese as 转山节 (about which F16 had already recorded a narrative). She chose to tell about all festivals involving mountains in the course of an entire year. Note: as a whole, the recording session conducted that day emphasized modern topics, modern tools, techniques and technology, and the vocabulary that came with them. This encouraged the consultant to use Chinese borrowings more lavishly than under previous circumstances, when the emphasis was on the old ways and the old ways.

crdo:item.dc:description: Tone Tutorial: the investigator read tone patterns reported in the monograph about tone in Yongning Na (Michaud 2017), which at the time of recording was nearing completion. The consultant was asked to check whether those productions were correct and intelligible way. This was one of several methods for verifying the findings. Thus, this is not phonological elicitation, but a recording of a work session in which the investigator asked the consultant to check whether he realized the tone patterns in a correct and intelligible way. If a pattern was OK, the consultant repeated it. If it was not, she provided a correction. (Part 3 of 3.) This document covers: Table 5.14 and Table 5.15.

crdo:item.dc:title: Tone tutorial: verification of tone patterns for a monograph (later published as Michaud 2017), part 3 of 3

crdo:item.dc:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
crdo:item.dc:description: Read syllables in a carrier sentence. This data set was devised for the study of tones and final consonants in Hanoi Vietnamese. The speaker lived in Hanoi until he came to France (9 months before the date of recording). These data were used for the following study: Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. In the study, this speaker (aged 24 at the time of recording) is referred to as M3. (en)# Corpus conçu pour l'étude des consonnes finales et de leurs relations avec les tons en vietnamien de Hanoi. Les items lus par l’informateur sont des rimes, qui peuvent se combiner avec les initiales (attaques), ou apparaître telles quelles (un coup de glotte étant réalisé en début de syllabe). La liste épuise la combinatoire des noyaux vocaliques avec les finales (nasales et occlusives). Les rimes avec occlusives finales sont réalisées selon les deux possibilités tonales existant en vietnamien. Les rimes avec consonnes nasales finales peuvent porter l’un des six tons de base. Elles sont ici uniquement associées avec le ton étymologique B2 (ton nặng), qui comporte une glottalisation finale. En effet, le propos de l’enregistrement est de mettre en lumière le contraste entre, d'une part l'absence de glottalisation sur les syllabes à occlusive finale, quel que soit le ton, et d'autre part la glottalisation finale des syllabes sans occlusive finale au ton B2 (ton nặng). Trois des items sont des logatomes, qui n’apparaissent dans aucun mot existant. Cette situation a été discutée avec le locuteur, qui lit chacun des items comme un « caractère » (chữ ; c’est le terme employé dans les deux phrases-cadre), sans chercher d’exemple de mot lexical comportant cette rime. Les syllabes étaient écrites sur des cartes de papier, de sorte que le locuteur voyait les syllabes l’une après l’autre et non sous forme de liste, pour éviter qu’elle n’accentue le contraste entre éléments successifs (par exemple, accentuer la différence de voyelle entre ọp et ợp (14 et 15), accentuer la différence de consonne entre ạch et ạc (36 et 37), accentuer la différence tonale entre ắc et ặc (2 et 3)), ce qui aurait créé un biais. Les items n’étaient pas présentés par séries ordonnées pour éviter les effets de liste. Le locuteur est né en 1979 à Hanoi (il avait 24 ans à la date de l’enregistrement). L'enregistrement a été réalisé par le locuteur alors qu'il était arrivé en France depuis 11 mois. Le début de son apprentissage du français remontait également à 11 mois. Ces données ont été employées dans l'étude suivante : Michaud, Alexis. 2004. Final consonants and glottalization: new perspectives from Hanoi Vietnamese. Phonetica 61(2–3). 119–146. Le locuteur y est désigné comme M3.
crdo:item.dc:subject: Northern Vietnamese

crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

ĐỐI THOẠI 2: Đối thoại được thiết kế cho việc nghiên cứu sự biến đổi đặc tính âm học của hai trợ từ tình thái cuối câu trong Tiếng Việt, thể hiện theo các thái độ khác nhau (Hà Nội)
crdo:item.dc:description: Information on FORM: This document (audio+EGG) is an edited version of the document Dialogues2, retaining only the sentences that were relevant for a study of sentence-final particles conducted in 2013. During data processing, the data sets for speakers M4 and M5 were edited to retain only the passages relevant for analysis. These documents are less complete than the set presented with XML annotation/transcription, and they are not time-aligned between the two speakers; they are nonetheless made available, in case they should be of interest, for instance to someone who wished to replicate our measurements over the data for all four speakers. In the version made available here, each file is annotated with the SoundForge software. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.

Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications
crdo:item.dc:title: DIALOGUES 2: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is an EDITED file, not an original (see description).

crdo:item.dc:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher. The items are not lexical: the reading task is based on the writing system: Naxi Pinyin 纳西拼音 (in Naxi: Naqxi Piyi).
